metadata.title: NumPy for Data Science: Part 1. NumPy Basics and Array Creation | by Rukshan Pramoditha | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: NumPy which stands for Numerical Python is one of the most important libraries (=packages or modules) in Python. This tutorial explains the basics of NumPy and various methods of array creation. It…

all_paragraphs: NumPy which stands for Numerical Python is one of the most important libraries (=packages or modules) in Python. This tutorial explains the basics of NumPy and various methods of array creation. It has been written for those who want to learn the basics and various functions of NumPy. To get the full advantage of this tutorial, you should be familiar with Python programming language and object-oriented programming (OOP) concepts.
In order to use the NumPy library, you need to import it in your program as in:
Alternatively, you can import the NumPy library using the following syntax.

By convention, the NumPy library is imported under the alias np. By doing this, you can access the functions, classes and sub-packages in the NumPy library using the np.namespace. [ex: np.array(), np.random.randn()]

NumPy’s main object is ndarray (which stands for N-dimensional array). This object is a multidimensional array of homogeneous data. Homogeneous refers to all elements in an array having the same data type.
The ndarray objects are created from the ndarray class which has many attributes and methods.
In NumPy, dimensions of an array are called the axes, and the number of dimensions is called the rank.

The following list shows the basic attributes of the ndarray class. A full list of attributes with descriptions is available in the ndarray docstring, which can be accessed by calling help(np.ndarray) in your Python interpreter.
To get help on a specific attribute of the ndarray class in NumPy, you can execute the following type of command.
You can create an array (an instance of the ndarray class) from a Python list or tuple using the array() function of NumPy. This array() function returns an ndarray object.
To get help on the NumPy array() function, you can execute the following command.
Note: When working with NumPy, data in an ndarray is simply referred to as an array.
As its name implies, a 1D array has one dimension.
We can create a 1D array by passing a list to the array() function of NumPy. One-dimensional arrays are returned as rows.
We can get the attributes of this ndarray object:
As its name implies, a 2D array has two dimensions.
We can create a 2D array by passing a list to the array() function of NumPy. Note that, this time, the elements of the list are also lists. Two-dimensional arrays are returned as matrices.
We can get the attributes of this ndarray object:
As its name implies, a 3D array has three dimensions.
We can create a 3D array by passing a list to the array() function of NumPy. Three-dimensional arrays are returned as lists of matrices.
We can get the attributes of this ndarray object:

Note: The array() function transforms sequences into one-dimensional arrays, sequences of sequences into two-dimensional arrays, sequences of sequences of sequences into three-dimensional arrays, and so on.

In addition to the NumPy array() function, there are a number of other functions for creating new arrays. As examples, zeros() and ones() create arrays of 0s or 1s, respectively, with a given length or shape.
arange() is an array-valued version of the built-in Python range function.

ones() return an array of given shape and type, filled with ones. By default, the dtype of the created array is np.float64. To create a one-dimensional array, you can just pass a positive integer for the shape argument. To create a higher-dimensional array with ones(), you can pass a tuple for the shape.
This is exactly the same as ones() but creates an array full of zeros.
identity() returns a square array with ones on the main diagonal and zeros elsewhere. The dtype parameter defaults to float.

eye() returns a 2D array where all elements are equal to zero, except the kth diagonal, whose values are equal to one. N is the number of rows. M is the number of columns. If you don’t specify the M, it defaults to N. k is the index of the diagonal. 0 (the default) refers to the main diagonal. A positive value refers to an upper diagonal, and a negative value to a lower diagonal.

The full() function returns an array of given shape and type, filled with fill_value. For a 1-dimensional array, shape is just an integer. To create a higher-dimensional array with full(), you can pass a tuple for the shape.

The randn() function of NumPy random subpackage returns an array in which elements are from the standard normal distribution. The dimensions of the returned array should be all positive. If no argument is given, a single Python float is returned.
To create a row vector, we simply create a one-dimensional array with one row.
To create a column vector, we need to create a two-dimensional array with one column.
Caution: A column vector is two-dimensional, not one-dimensional. We can inspect this using ndarray.ndim and ndarray.shape attributes.
This tutorial was designed and created by Rukshan Pramoditha, the Author of Data Science 365 Blog.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
